subject: Re: Letter connections and syllable boundaries (or, the spelling of "kangaroo")

messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
<freeman@...> wrote:
>

> Connections between letters are not allowed to cross a syllable
boundary.
>

I think this may be a solid rule, at least for typography. The word
"arrest" then becomes

Ado | Roar+ Ed Sis Tut

The connection tells us what sounds to put together.

Merry becomes

Mime + Ed | Roar + Eat

Area becomes

Ash + Roar | Eat + Ado

Note though, the difference between the words "arrest" and "area."
Let's say we keep things the way they are, and that we spell both
words without ligatures. With "arrest," a reader can become initially
confused. With "area," I don't think the same confusion is possible,
because whether you group the Roar with the first vowel or with the
second, you can sound out the words on the first try. Thinking this
through, the confusion with "arrest" must result because the Ado +
Roar combination really makes a phoneme not present in Read, namely
the /3/. So I suppose in answer to your earlier thread, in which I
said how much I liked our chart, it seems only the Earth ligature
should get special status, should perhaps be elevated to letter-hood.
(Good job to whoever invented that phrase!)

Paul
